headline: Warner Bros. Discovery shares edge lower on Paramount Skydance bid

headline: Paramount, Netflix's bidding war 'underscores' Warner Bros. value
summary: Paramount Skydance (PSKY) has revised and ramped up its offer to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), challenging Netflix's (NFLX) own bid for the media giant. Sevens Report Research founder Tom Essaye, Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Ines Ferré, and Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre all weigh in on whether Paramount's new deal is sweet enough for WBD to reconsider a sale to streamer Netflix. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: PARAMOUNT CONFIRMS SUBMISSION OF REVISED PROPOSAL TO ACQUIRE WARNER BROS. DISCOVERY

(NASDAQ: WBD) ("WBD") a revised proposal to acquire WBD. This submission follows a period of engagement with WBD after it received a seven-day waiver under its merger agreement with Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ: NFLX) to engage with Paramount.

headline: Paramount bids higher for Warner Bros to block Netflix: source
summary: STORY: Paramount has submitted a higher offer for Warner Bros Discovery in an attempt to derail a deal with Netflix. That’s according to a source familiar with the matter. The bidding war for one of Hollywood’s most coveted underscores a desire for dominance in the streaming-led market. With Warner Bros being home to HBO Max, and franchises including “Harry Potter” and “Game of Thrones”. The source said Paramount’s new bid, which improves its initial offer of $104.8 billion, seeks to address Warner Bros' concerns about the certainty of its financing.Netflix, which offered to buy it for $27.75 per share or $82.7 billion, is allowed to match the latest bid from Paramount.A Variety report said that the iconic studio was likely to take the Paramount offer under review while still recommending the Netflix pact to its shareholders.Netflix has ample cash and could bump up its offer  - while Paramount's rival bid is backed by Oracle billionaire Larry Ellison.Warner Bros shareholders were set to decide the fate of Netflix's offer on March 20.A green light from investors would move the deal forward - but it’d still face intense scrutiny from U.S. and European competition authorities. These bodies must assess whether combining Netflix's global streaming power with Warner Bros' century-old studio assets would reduce competition or limit consumer choice.

raw.headline: Paramount bids higher for Warner Bros to block Netflix: source
raw.summary: STORY: Paramount has submitted a higher offer for Warner Bros Discovery in an attempt to derail a deal with Netflix. That’s according to a source familiar with the matter. The bidding war for one of Hollywood’s most coveted underscores a desire for dominance in the streaming-led market. With Warner Bros being home to HBO Max, and franchises including “Harry Potter” and “Game of Thrones”. The source said Paramount’s new bid, which improves its initial offer of $104.8 billion, seeks to address Warner Bros' concerns about the certainty of its financing.Netflix, which offered to buy it for $27.75 per share or $82.7 billion, is allowed to match the latest bid from Paramount.A Variety report said that the iconic studio was likely to take the Paramount offer under review while still recommending the Netflix pact to its shareholders.Netflix has ample cash and could bump up its offer  - while Paramount's rival bid is backed by Oracle billionaire Larry Ellison.Warner Bros shareholders were set to decide the fate of Netflix's offer on March 20.A green light from investors would move the deal forward - but it’d still face intense scrutiny from U.S. and European competition authorities. These bodies must assess whether combining Netflix's global streaming power with Warner Bros' century-old studio assets would reduce competition or limit consumer choice.

headline: Regulatory And Political Scrutiny Puts Netflix Warner Bros Deal Under Review
summary: Netflix (NasdaqGS:NFLX) is pursuing a high profile bid to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, drawing close scrutiny from regulators and politicians. The US Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation into the proposed transaction. Former President Trump has publicly called for the removal of Netflix board member Susan Rice, raising additional political pressure around the deal. Competing bidders and criticism from prominent entertainment industry figures are adding to the...
